column11: The Marble Beach surf was calm and relaxing, just perfect for a long and leisurely dip in the sea! I encountered many aqua-colored luminescent jelly fish floating in the water, but not the painful stinging kind so no worries. They were sooo beautiful. There were large cabanas and trees on the beach for shade and for stashing gear. If you come by motorbike or tuk tuk, don't leave anything unsecured with your vehicle because you will probably lose it to a monkey. The morning was especially nice as there were just a few people swimming. By mid afternoon, throngs of wild (but good natured) teenage boys descended onto the beach. This is a public space with lifeguards who will blow their whistle if they deem you too far from shore. Bummer because the sea is very shallow for a long, long way. I was there in March and at that time approximately 65% of the beach was cordoned off by the police/military. Reason unknown, but the restricted area consisted of a long crescent of premium beach including the coral reef. At that time it was not possible to go snorkeling. The photo that accompanies this listing shows the whole beach, including what is now restricted. If your prime objective is a safe ocean swim, Marble Beach is a solid choice, just come early in the day.

column11: The best beach in Sri Lanka. That's a bold claim but I'll stand by it. I've been beach hunting in out of the way parts of the country for years and I've never found anything that surpasses Marble Beach. On a clear day during the east coast season not Hawaii or even the Maldives is better. Equal maybe but you can‚Äôt really beat perfection. This is simply the post-card perfect, castaway beach from your imagination incarnate. Crystal clear, dazzlingly blue water with gentle transparent waves rolling towards powder-white sand. Lush scrub jungle reaches from the edge of the sand up the adjacent hill. The proximity of a living forest means you can see monkeys and peacocks even as shoals of brightly colored fish swim around your ankles - an experience the Maldives will never match. You also aren't ever going to be alone on a Maldivian-resort's stretch of sand, while you still stand every chance of being the only person on Marble beach.

column11: Marble Beach and Resort This resort situated off Kinniya Road, Trincomalee, in the east coast of Sri Lanka, 266 KM and 5 hrs by car, from Colombo  where the best time to visit begins late March. I was pleasantly surprised how clean the beach despite it is the off season with high winds and rough sea. All credit should go to the Sri Lanka Air Force personnel who maintain this place. The beach is divided into two sections one for the day trippers  (fee charged) and he other half for exclusive use of resort residents. The bay overlook Trincomalee harbor and the Chalets overlook the sea. We were in the Banyan chalet, a rustic but with basic necessities  like Cable TV, fridge etc. In the background is a forested hill which I believe has good scenic lookouts though we were unable to climb due to seasonal rains. The Veranda of the chalet offers an uninterrupted view of the harbour the Islands. The far end of the  resort section of the beach is littered  with rocks, pebbles of varying size which get covered during high tide where one can spend hours observing marine life. The resort is an idyllic place to spend the day beginning with  the majestic sunrise and  the sea birds darting into water for prey in he evening. Apart from Whale watching, visits to interesting places in Trincomalee one can also visit the serene Welgam Vehera, a temple located about 15 mins drive from the resort. This temple built 2000 years ago was  almost vandalized by the LTTE terrorists. Food prepared by the the resort personnel was tasty and they make it a point to ask what we like for the next meal at every meal. We had very good Crab and Prawn Curry together with fresh vegetables. Fruits were in abundance and served with every meal.  The staff was extremely friendly to say the least. The only downside of our visit was the few mosquitoes bothering us perhaps due to puddles remaining after the rains. There was also slight offensive smell in the chalet on day one, which perhaps due to the cleaning liquids used. There are two main roads leading to this resort, the A6 and A12. On the A6 after Habarana town one could most often see wild elephants on either side of the main road enjoying the lush green grass especially in late afternoons. A12 road from Anuradhapura the ancient city to Trincomalee offer fantastic drive through the middle of two large reservoir Mahadivulwewa and MahaKanadarawa where kayaking is possible, and with a history dating back to 300AD. A large Crocodile was seen  sunbathing in one of the smaller village tank driving on A 12. Both these picturesque main routes, A 6 and A 12 have been renovated and rehabilitated beyond expectations after terrorism ended in May 2009.

column11: Before I write my experience, I need to put things into perspective so that the appropriate audience can be guided. The problems lie if there are women in the group and they tend to expose a little more skin than you would typically see in such a location. My sister was not even on the beach, and there was a military guy who was secretly filming her or taking pictures with his cell phone camera. You basically have a bunch of military men running a resort with no etiquette on being respectful to women. I can only imagine if a bunch of women were to travel to this location by themselves. Who is to know what could transpire? So given this experience, I would never encourage females and certainly not Westerners (women) to visit this so called "resort" in Trincomalee. column11: This has a wonderfully wide clean beach with thick vegetation surrounding it. The ocean is shallow and ideal for relaxing in water, swimming, and play. For the most part of the day you can have the beach all to yourself. There are at least two lifeguards on duty all the time. Only part of this beach is accessible to the public. The large part of the beach is a private beach operated by the Sri Lanka Air Force with it's wonderful bungalows, dinning areas and chalets. The food we had there was one of the neatest and most well prepared Sri Lankan style meals we had in Sri Lanka. The service provided by the staff was highest quality(Felt like they were under the command of someone all the time :)) Upon inquiry we were told all these guys have gone through at least the basic military training. We were here in June 2013.The two rooms we occupied were basic, yet spacious clean and comfortable, had air conditioning, and bath rooms were extremely clean. Linen and pillows were fresh. Next time we go to Sri Lanka we will plan on staying here longer and will definitely stay at one of the over the water bungalows. Also there is a wonderful wooded hiking trail that takes you to another little cove ideal for swimming and pictures.

column11: Marble Beach is a great swimming and lunch stop. It's an unspoilt beach with an Army barracks at the back of the beach. Generous portions, surprisingly good food and not over-priced. Great selection of drinks too. We spent over 2 hours over lunch! Rs.20 entrance fee per person incl tuk tuk driver to marble beach. We had the best day with Mohan (+94 (0) 779017207). For Rs.2,200 he picked us up at 9am took us shopping for lungis/sarongs, found us great local breakfast, took us to all the places we wanted to go (Suwami Rock and temple, Marble Beach etc...). We spent so much time at Marble Beach  that by the time we topped up our phones, collected our lungis, got take away dinner etc. it was already 7pm! So we didn't get a chance to see the hot pools but Mohan was prepared to take us anywhere that we wanted to go for the same price within a certain time frame (which we clearly went over!) For Rs.250 he delivered red wine and takeaways to our hotel in Uppuveli (6kms away) - there was just nothing that he wasn't prepared to do for us. He was so kind and easy to be around. I shed a tear when we left because his kindness and generosity had touched me so much. And he does not take commission if he collects you from the bus station and takes you to a guesthouse. For Rs.250 he took us from the bus station to three different guesthouses on Uppuveli Beach (6kms away) until we decided which one we wanted. He did not come inside so he had nothing to do with the prices we negotiated with the hotel we stayed at. Whether or not something was arranged without our knowing we'll never know, but I think he was sincere. Genuine human being!

column11: What can one say? The Marble Beach is simply breathtaking! Nowhere in Sri Lanka can one ever find such a beautiful beach and a memorizing sea! column11: I visited  The Marble Beach Air Force Resort Hotel,  maintained by the Air Force , this November.  We wanted to have an evening at the beach with sun , sea and of course, lots of fun.
